]]><![CDATA[[CSS] Arthur's Nightlight (one handed)]]>I originally created this in the few months after Arthur was born, during a period where I was simultaneously taking much needed parental leave, and learning about front-end code.  I had originally wrote this blurb about my experience:

When I'm not working on my front-end skills, I'm likely spending time
]]>http://localhost:2368/arthurs-nightlight-css-demo/5c61e513d899247ad0f7be1bTue, 12 Feb 2019 07:35:49 GMTI originally created this in the few months after Arthur was born, during a period where I was simultaneously taking much needed parental leave, and learning about front-end code.  I had originally wrote this blurb about my experience:

When I'm not working on my front-end skills, I'm likely spending time with my son, or just trying to get him to go to bed. I've spent quite a bit of time in the last few months in a dark room while I swaddle / shush / swing him to sleep. So often, in fact, I felt compelled to recreate his nightlight from memory.

I can't believe I can even remember coding this demo. Man, I can't.  OK, I have an excuse because of the sleep depredation, but I do remember this part:

I did this a majority project with one hand.

A lot of the initial layout and composition was done by manually adapting a very rough SVG draft (I mean... rough) to an HTML struct.

Then... I did what nature does.  I bent shape into a light and... voila.
How did I bend it exactly? Well... a lot of < ^ > and +- keys.

Through a combination of absolute positioning, well-timed %, and several view-port metrics, I remember being very excited at some of the responsive behaviors I was able to obtain out of this little .toy object.

There's definitely some issues when used on other browsers, and I fixed a few through a few more burbs and knee bounces.  Overall, there's not a lot of practical uses for something like this, but I feel I learned a lot about the ways you can re-shape essential CSS elements, in addition to exploring newer browser APIs.

]]><![CDATA[[Technical Content] Speedtest Custom Migration]]>Ookla – the team behind Speedtest.net – also offer an enterprise version of their flagship website software used to measure bandwidth and latency between a client and server.  During the transition from Speedtest.net from legacy Flash protocols to new HTML5 transition, I lead a small team of technical service contractors

]]>http://localhost:2368/untitled/5c61d6c50d49cd4a4541df09Mon, 11 Feb 2019 20:11:03 GMTOokla – the team behind Speedtest.net – also offer an enterprise version of their flagship website software used to measure bandwidth and latency between a client and server.  During the transition from Speedtest.net from legacy Flash protocols to new HTML5 transition, I lead a small team of technical service contractors to assist with the increase workload from the transition.

While in beta, we spent a few weeks trying to understand some of the obstacles between the previous version and next version and finally compiled steps necessary in a support document.

https://support.ookla.com/hc/en-us/sections/115000458632-NetGauge-Migration

The document was broken into 3 sections as to help compartmentalize the steps required and allowed us to assist users through each step of the process, rather than having to read one guide from top to bottom in case they got stuck.

  • How Do I Upgrade to Speedtest Custom from NetGauge?
  • Compatibility of your existing NetGauge OoklaServer Daemon
  • Updating your NetGauge site to host the STC test

Immediately after publishing this resource, the number of requests well field slowly went down as this resource was distributed from technical service team.  

]]><![CDATA[[Technical Content] NinjaTrader 8 Code Breaking Changes]]>http://localhost:2368/ninjatrader-8-code-breaking-changes/5c61d2f20d49cd4a4541ded0Mon, 11 Feb 2019 20:10:00 GMT
  • I was JR. Product Manager
  • Responsible for interrupting legacy documentation, APIs, and code reviews to adapt to new technology
  • Inherited project from form product manager
  • Worked in efforts to fill in gaps where needed between custom requests and existing API code that could be exposed
  • Worked with developers to help understand expected code functionality and develop reasonable API behaviors and errors that would foster an "exploratory" meaner
  • Fundamentally changed many core events, GUI framework, and exposed low-level accessibility to fulfill change requests between major release cycles
  • Rehashed user experiences working with customer-facing teams, company stakeholders, and key partners to help ensure the milestone transition between products was seamless.
  • Painstakingly reviewed implementations and changes with quality to teams to ensure consistency between naming, color, and sub-class behaviors
